{{about||the entity|Monster (entity)|other uses|Monster (disambiguation)}}
[[File:OverWorld Monsters.png|260px|right|thumb|Some of the many common monsters from ''[[Minecraft]]''.]]

The term '''Monster''' refers to a category of [[mob]]s that are mainly hostile to the [[player]].

== Common properties ==
Mobs mentioned on this page share the following properties to be classified as monsters:
* They are either classified as enemies in the [[entity format]] or in [[Mob spawning|spawning mechanics]], such as the [[mob cap]].
** Monsters that spawn by weight, as well as skeleton horse traps, will never spawn if game rule {{cd|spawn_monsters}} is set to false.

Although this doesn't affect their classification, ''most'' of them share the following properties, but with exceptions:
*They despawn or don't spawn naturally in [[Peaceful]] difficulty.
* Prevent the player from [[Bed#Sleeping|sleeping]].
* Drop more than 1-3 [[experience]] orbs.
* Use the "Hostile Mobs" sound category.
* Trigger the "Monster Hunter" [[advancement]] and "Monsters Hunted" challenge.{{only|java|short=1}}
* Trigger the "Monster Hunter" [[achievement]].{{only|bedrock|short=1}}
* [[Iron golem]]s and [[snow golem]]s will target them.
* [[Parrot]]s will imitate their sounds.
* An active [[conduit]] will damage them.
* Worried [[panda]]s{{only|java|short=1}} and [[rabbit]]s will avoid them.
* They can’t be [[leashed]].

== Trivia ==
* The [[warden]] is the only fully hostile monster (as [[skeleton horse]]s are passive when not mounted) that spawns naturally that does not count towards the Monster Hunter advancement or Monsters Hunted challenge.
** The reason for this is because the warden is not intended to be slain, and is instead meant to be evaded.
* [[Polar bear]]s were once classified as monsters valid for advancements. This property was removed in snapshot [[19w14a]].
* [[Strider]]s are internally referred to as monsters,<ref>{{cd|net/minecraft/world/entity/monster/Strider}}</ref> however this does not affect gameplay, as the strider does not share the same traits as actual in-game monsters, being considered an [[animal]] instead. The same thing applies to happy ghasts, which despite being a passive counterpart of the normal ghast, are also considered animals instead of monsters.
